An initial public offering
when a successful private company
decides to offer share to the public
is an exciting time for the company
it original shareholder and the investing public .
All of the excitement and publicity around an IPO
often lead investor to want to get in on the action .
If you can get in on the ground floor of an IPO
that is get an allocation in the initial share offering
before the stock start trading
there is evidence that you are likely to make a profit .
IPOs tend to be underpriced .
While this might seem like an obvious way to easy profit
there are a few crucially important thing
for you to consider .
I 'm Ben Felix Portfolio Manager at PWL Capital .
In this episode of Common Sense Investing
I 'm going to tell you why IPOs do n't live up to the hype .
( driving electronic music )
It is well that IPOs tend to be underpriced .
In other word when the underwriter determines the price
that the company should offer it share to the public
the data show that they tend to set a price
below where the market will price the share .
This creates the perception
of a real opportunity for investor
to make a quick profit on the first day of an IPO .
The medium often enjoy reporting
on the large first profit that IPO investor make .
The challenge for most investor though
is that getting in on the initial allocation is really hard .
The majority of the initial allocation
generally go to institutional investor
which we will touch on again in a minute
while the allotment for retail investor
is likely to be allocated to larger brokerage client .
Fidelity describes the allocation process
for retail investor a follows .
Each customer who want to participate in an IPO offering
is evaluated and ranked based on his or her asset
and the revenue they generate for the brokerage firm .
Typically customer with significant
long relationship with their brokerage firm
will receive higher priority
than those with smaller or new relationship .
This statement from Fidelity is supported
by a 2018 paper in the Journal of Fice titled
`` Quid Pro Quo ?
What Factors Influence IPO Allocations to Investors ? ``
where the author examined 220 IPOs
from January 2010 through May 2015
to test the determit of IPO allocation .
They found strong support
for the brokerage revenue associated with a client
being a significant determit
of investor ' IPO allocation and profit .
Based on this if you are able
to get in on an initial allocation
unless you 're a high value brokerage client
or an institution
you 're likely getting in on an IPO
with a poor expected outcome .
There is adverse selection in IPO allotment
where those with expected weak first return
have been easier to get access to ahead of time .
I think it 's safe to say that in general
smaller retail investor and DIY investor
who are not generating significant revenue
for their brokerage firm
will be hard pressed to get in on the initial allocation
when a hot company go public .
Interestingly there is evidence that new mutual fund
use their institutional status and relationship
to get in on initial IPO allocation
in an effort to boost their return .
This wa detailed in a 2017 paper
`` IPO Allocations and New Mutual Funds ''
by Frankie Chau Yi Gu and Christodoulos Louca .
They looked at data from 1998 to 2015
and found that new mutual fund tend to outperform
during the first six month after inception .
This outperformance wa concentrated
in new fund that held underpriced IPO stock .
After the first six month performance fell substantially .
The suggestion in the paper
is that a fund company might choose to allocate
all of their IPO allotment to a new fund
in an effort to boost it performance
to attract new investor .
While this work to get an initial boost
the fund performance tends to drop off quickly .
The reason that this information
is relevant to our discussion
is that it show the level of competition
for initial IPO allotment .
I would n't take this a a signal
that all new mutual fund will perform well .
Keep in mind it is easy to identify the fund
receiving preferential IPO allocation after the fact
but I would n't start speculating on new mutual fund
in an effort to profit from this phenomenon .
All right so you 're probably not going to get in
on the initial allocation when a company go public
but that doe n't mean that you ca n't buy share
on the first day of trading .
Once the share are listed on a stock exchange
many of the people holding the share
will want to realize the profit
from the likely underpriced IPO
and you could be the one to buy them .
The performance of IPOs after the first day of trading
ha also been studied extensively .
In the March 2017 paper
`` The Long Performance of IPOs Revisited ''
Daniel Hoechle Larissa Karthaus and Markus Schmid
detailed the performance of US IPOs between 1975 and 2014 .
They looked at a total of 7
over time period ranging from one to 40 quarter
after the first trading day .
They found that IPO firm tended to behave
like high beta stock
with negative loading to the value factor
and that they underperform for the first two year
even when common risk factor
like size relative price and momentum are accounted for .
This underperformance gradually decline
with longer time period
becoming statistically insignificant after two year .
In summary of their paper
IPO firm have unfavorable exposure to risk factor
with high beta and negative loading to value
but even when those are accounted for
IPO firm tend to underperform for the first two year .
These finding are also supported by more recent research .
In a 2019 paper from Dimensional Fund Advisors
the author examined 6
between January 1991 and December 2018 .
To evaluate IPO performance a a whole
they constructed a hypothetical
market weighted portfolio of IPOs
issued over the preceding 12 period
and rebalanced monthly .
They excluded first return from the analysis .
They found that over the full sample period
the IPO portfolio delivered a return of 6.93 %
with a standard deviation of 27.62 %
while the Russell 3000 Index a US total market index
delivered a 9.13 % return with a 14.28 % standard deviation .
They also split the full sample period into two sub
with one ending in the year 2000
to isolate the high volume of IPOs over that time period .
The result for both sub
before and after the year 2000
exhibited underperformance relative to the market
with substantially more risk
a measured by the standard deviation of return .
This result corroborates the finding
of Hoechle Karthaus and Schmid
who found that IPOs perform poorly over the first two year .
The Dimensional paper also applied
the Fama/French five model
to the IPO portfolio ' return
and found that the return are well explained
by the factor in the model
market beta company size relative price
profitability and investment .
This suggests that IPO firm a a group
have behaved like small cap growth stock
with weak profitability that invest aggressively .
These type of stock whether they are recent IPOs or not
tend to underperform the market .
What we can conclude from the research
that we have discussed in this video is that
if you want to make money from IPOs
you have to get in on the initial allocation
but doing so especially for hot IPOs
is really unlikely unless you are considered
a highly valued client by your brokerage .
If you are able to get in on the initial allocation
there 's a good chance that it 's not an IPO
that will have a big first pop .
The better the expected pop
the more likely the IPO share will be allotted
to institution and the largest retail client .
If you miss out on the initial allocation
and instead buy the share on the secondary market
once they 've started trading
you 're buying into share that will likely perform
like a small growth low profitability
high investment firm
which have an unattractive risk/return profile .
Even beyond that let 's keep in mind that
any time that you buy one stock
you probably are n't going to get the return
of the asset class that it belongs to .
On average a secondary market IPO investment
will give you the poor expected outcome
of small growth low profitability high investment stock .
But unless you are building
a diversified portfolio of recent IPO stock
your actual outcome on an individual stock investment
will be driven by the specific risk of the company
which delivers a random outcome .

My name is Alex Lyon and I 'm here to

are some good way to start and some bad way . We 're going to look at the top 5 way to start
presentation . For the first is a story . And I mean a brief story like 30 second
to 60 second .
It can be humorous . It can be fun light could be serious .
Whatever match the tone of the central message you 're about to share is appropriate
And it also should in it content drive towards the heart of the message . For

young he wa driving this truck on the freeway . It wa a cherry picker huge truck with

your presentation . Second way is a statistic or fact .
Ideally a statistic that 's startling something a little unexpected . Like I

during college student have about eight hundred dollar worth of credit card
debt but by the time they are in the working world they have about eight
thousand dollar worth of credit card debt . Now to me that 's pretty startling .
And if you were going to open a presentation about personal fice or
perhaps college student whatever the topic is that is an example of a good
statistic because it really draw your attention to the issue .
So a you 're doing your research you 'll probably come across some

or attention material for your opening . The third way is rhetorical question .
A rhetorical question a they say is not necessarily a question that need to be
answered .

and then you insert your question . I think it 's a great way to start because

Layout and composition .
In a way they 're the foundation of design .
They give your work structure and make it easier to navigate from the margin on the
side ... to the content in between .
Of course it 's not just about working with text .
Composition matter in other medium too like graphic design web design and much
more .
Without a well layout your work would basically ... fall apart .
The key to mastering layout and composition is to think like a designer .
Luckily it 's easier than it sound .
There are five basic principle that can help you transform your work and sharpen your eye
for design .
Let 's start at the top and work our way down .
Proximity is all about using visual space to show relationship in your content .
In practice it 's pretty simple?all you have to do is make sure related item are
grouped together ; for example block of text or element in a graphic .
Groups that are not related to each other should be separated to visually emphasize
their lack of a relationship .
All in all this make your work easier to understand at a glance?whether it 's purely
text or something more visual .
White space is an important part of every composition .
Now this doe n't mean literal `` white space '' ?it just mean negative space like the space
between your content between line and even the outer margin .
There 's no `` one way '' to use white space correctly but it 's good to understand it purpose .
White space help you define and separate different section ; it give your content
room to breath .
If your work ever start to feel cluttered or uncomfortable? a little white space might
be just what the doctor ordered .
Alignment is something you deal with all the time even if you do n't realize it .
Whenever you type an email or create a document the text is aligned automatically .
When aligning object by yourself ( for instance image or separate text box ) getting it
right can be tricky .
The most important thing is to be consistent .
Let 's take a look at what that mean .
It might help to imagine your content arranged inside of a grid .
Notice how there 's an invisible line centering each image to the text ?
Each grouping is also evenly spaced and aligned with equal margin .
It 's that attention to detail that make the composition easier to navigate .
Without consistent alignment your work could start to feel disorganized .
Contrast simply mean that one item is different from another .
In layout and composition contrast can help you do many thing ; for example catch the
reader 's eye create emphasis or call attention to something important .
There are lot of strategy or creating contrast .
You can use color ... adjust the size shape or visual weight of an object ... or use contrasting
style of text .
Contrast is also closely tied to hierarchy a visual technique that can help the viewer
navigate you work .
In other word it show them where to begin and where to go next using different level
of emphasis .
Establishing hierarchy is simple : just decide which element you want the reader to notice
first then make them stand out .
High or important item are usually larger bolder or more eye in some
way .
Repetition is a reminder that every project should have a consistent look and feel .
That mean finding way to reinforce your design by repeating or echoing certain element .
For instance if you have a specific color palette look for way to carry it through .
If you 've chosen a special header style use it every time .
It 's not just for aesthetic reasons?being consistent can also make your work easier
to read .
When the viewer know what to expect they can relax and focus on the content .
In many way layout and composition are the unsung hero of design .
It 's easy to overlook their role but they 're part of everything you do .
A nudge here ... some extra white space there ... and voila !
With a little attention to detail you can create beautiful professional composition .
Thanks for joining u for the basic of layout and composition .
Check out the rest of our design topic including typography color and image .

If you really want to add some excitement to your presentation try adding some animation .
PowerPoint ha a wide variety of animated effect that can be applied to text and other
object .
In this example I 'm creating a very basic quiz that ha a question on each slide .
I 'd like to add animation to these two text box ... and also the man on top of the moon .
To get started select the first object you want you want to animate ... then go to the
Animations tab .
Next click the drop down arrow to see all the available effect .
There are four different category : Entrance which will happen when the object
first appears ...
Emphasis which happens while the object is on the slide ...
Exit which will cause the object to disappear ...
And Motion Paths which will move the object along a path .
I 'm going to choose the one called Fly In which is an Entrance effect .
For some effect you 'll have different Effect Options that you can choose from .
As you can see this one let you change the direction .
Let 's say I wanted to add second animation to the text .
If we try to select one from the main menu it 's actually going to replace the current
effect .
Instead we 'll click the command that say Add Animation ... and we can apply additional
effect to the same object .
You can always tell which object have animation because they 'll have little number next to
them?one for each effect .
The thumbnail for the slide will also have a star icon .
If you want to preview the effect just click the Preview command any time .
Now the key to using animation effectively is moderation .
Say we wanted to add an effect to the answer text a well .
We do n't want anything too bold like say the Swivel effect because it might be distracting
to the audience .
Instead I 'm just going to set it to slowly fade in which should really help the answer
shine .
It 's also important to note that not every object need an animation .
This is especially true in more corporate or professional setting .
In this case we 're creating a fairly casual presentation?so I 'm going to add one more
effect to our little astronaut but leave the rest of the slide alone .
At this point we have several animation to keep track of so it might be a good time
to open the Animation Pane .
The pane appears on the right and let you do a few different thing .
You can click and drag the effect to change the order that they play in ... and you can
use the drop arrow to access even more option .
By default animation are set to start when you click the mouse but I do n't want to have
to do that for every single one .
Instead we can have some of them start automatically either with the previous effect or after .
I 'm going to choose After for everything but the very first animation .
That way they 'll all play one after the other a soon a we click the mouse .
If you go back to the drop arrow ... and then choose Effect Options from the menu ...
you 'll get a dialog box where you can really fine the effect .
Some of these option will vary depending on the specific animation you 're working with .
For example with this animation ... we can set the answer to fade in all at once one
word at a time or one letter at a time .
I want a little bit more flair so I 'm going to go ahead and choose by letter .
If we go to the Timing tab ... we can adjust thing like the speed of the effect and whether
or not it repeat .
I 'm going to add a tiny bit of delay to give the audience more time to think of the answer .
And that look perfect !
Now I 'm going to play the entire slide show so we can see the finished product .
We 'll just click the mouse to trigger the first effect ... which trigger the next one
automatically ... and then the next one .
I really like the way the answer animation turned out so I 'd like to use the same one
on the other question slide .
Luckily we do n't have to go through all the step again?we can just copy and paste the
effect from one object to another .
First select the object whose animation you want to copy ... then click the command that
say Animation Painter .
Next click whatever object you want to add the effect to ... and now it fade in in exactly
the same way .
We 're well on our way to creating a fun practice quiz .
With just a few animation you can turn a simple slide show into something interesting
and engaging .

Hello I 'm Callie .
What 's the fastest way to tell the difference between a speech and a presentation ?
It 's audio .
Today we 'll talk about the importance of visual aid .
Thanks for visiting Toastmasters International .
Since 1924 we 've helped more than 4 million people gain the confidence to communicate
in all circumstance .
One of the most demanding situation you 'll ever face is speaking to an audience .
This video is part of a series of Toastmasters ' time tip that will help you become
a more confident speaker .
In this video we 'll explore simple and effective way to make the most of visual aid .
Let 's begin with a few simple way to add flare to your next speech by incorporating
visual aid .
When presenting for business the most commonly tool are a computer and projector and with
the help of presentation software image can be projected in sequence on a large screen
that even people in the back of the room can easily see .
Additionally presentation software make it easier for you to include a short video ;
however keep in mind that when you play a video that ha audio you 'll need to have a
pair of external speaker .
Most built laptop speaker lack the power needed to increase volume so everyone in the
room can hear .
Another important tool is the remote control .
This wireless handheld device allows you to advance your presentation without having to
step over the laptop every time you want to advance to the next slide or picture .
Projecting an image on the screen can help the audience visually grasp your point and
a prop can add an extra dimension to your presentation .
Visual aid are a great way to keep the audience interested .
When you want to brainstorm with the audience get back to basic by incorporating a flip
chart or white board .
For this type of exercise there is no better tool .
On the spot you can grab your listener idea and jot them down .
The rapid exchange is fun and the audience feel more invested in the experience by seeing
their word and idea come to life before them .
Now that we 've identified the key support tool let 's take a look at we can effectively
interact with visual aid .
If you plan to present with a slide deck you have to prepare for Murphy 's Law .
`` Who is Murphy and what 's his law ? '' you ask .
It 's the idea that if anything can go wrong it will .
In preparation be ready for technical glitch by printing up a backup copy of your presentation
slide .
No matter what happens to the audio or video equipment you 'll be fully prepared to stand
and deliver because you have your printed slide and talking point with you .
When it come to setting up your visual aid arrive early to the venue to position your
material in the best location .
If you 're working with a computer test it to be sure you can see your presentation deck
on the screen .
Honoring Murphy 's Law always carry a backup copy of your slide deck on a USB drive to
remedy possible technical problem that may arise .
Be aware that presenting with visual aid can be troublesome .
For instance telling a story about a bear when you have a picture of a rowboat on the
screen can confuse the audience .
Always remember that the image on the screen must relate to the story you 're sharing in
order for your story and you to have credibility .
Similarly do n't feel tempted to use video just because it 's an option .
A frivolous video that doe n't support your message is a distraction .
So choose video that will reinforce your point .
While slide can help you stay on track they also create another challenge they increase
the number of spoken transition in your presentation .
Every time you click on the next slide you 'll need to verbally take the audience from one
slide idea to the next to make the story feel seamless and fluid .
And last but not least it 's time to concentrate on the final consideration : the you factor .
The most prominent visual aid in the front of the room is you .
And that 's why it 's crucial that you pay close attention to your personal style .
Are the clothes you are wearing in line with your message ?
If you 're ever in doubt with how to dress follow this simple rule : raise your style
one level higher than the audience 's .
For instance if they 're dressed casually then dress in line with business casual style .
The way we move physically also play a part in our visual credibility .
Avoid moving too much or too little because both can be distracting .
Pay special attention that your gesture and movement support your story .
Incorporate these tip and technique and before you know it you 'll have mastered the
art of making the most of visual aid .
For more information on making the most of visual aid visit a Toastmasters club .
Find a location near you at toastmasters.org .

In this lecture we 're looking at
highlighting visual aid and that mean
two thing : first focusing the audience 's
attention on your visual aid ; and second
stating the visual 's general meaning . When
you are presenting a visual aid to the
audience and you want them to look at it
to pay attention to it there are some
key expression that you can use .
Probably the most common is this :
`` Ok let 's take a look at this slide ; '' or `` Ok
let 's take a look at this chart . ''
`` Ok let 's take a look at this graph . '' Or if
you want to speak more formally in a
very formal presentation you may use
this expression : `` I 'd like to draw your
attention to this chart . '' Or `` I 'd like to
draw your attention to this graph . ''
more formal expression there . So that 's
focusing the audience 's attention . In
other word you just saying to the
audience `` look at this slide . ''
`` Look at this chart . '' `` Look at this graph . ''
Now that 's the first step . The second
step is to tell the audience what they
are looking at . What is it ?
And here are some expression here for
doing that : `` As you can see this is our
sale data for the past quarter . '' `` Here we
can see the number of word spoken per
minute . '' `` Here we can see the growth of
bacteria over time . '' So stating the visual 's
general meaning . You might also choose to
use one of these expression :
`` This slide show our sale data . '' `` This next
chart illustrates the number of word
spoken ; '' or `` This graph refers to the
growth of bacteria over time . '' So some
various expression there for stating
the visual 's general meaning ; in other
word answering the question `` What are we
looking at ? ''
And another way to do that if you have a
line graph is to talk about the
different type of line and we 're going

more information from the supplement to

but basically in a line graph there are
three type of line : there 's a solid
line ; a broken line ; and a dotted line . And
you can use these with various verb : so
the solid line show the growth over
time ; the broken line illustrates
employee retention ; the dotted line
refers to sale figure . So three type
of line and again we 're going to get
more into that later .
